G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore this Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County because the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Boston, Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all operators of motor vehicles owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable injury to others using the public ways, including bicyclists.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The case is about premises and contractor negligence arising from a scaffolding collapse at a residential construction site; it does not involve motor vehicles, public ways, or duties owed by vehicle operators to bicyclists or other roadway users. The court’s discussion focuses on duty, breach, and causation in the context of a property owner/general contractor relationship and statutory building code duties, not traffic or roadway negligence. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition concerning Massachusetts motorists’ duty of reasonable care toward bicyclists on public ways.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B(2).proposition: A bicyclist traveling in a designated bicycle lane has the rights and duties of the driver of any other vehicle, except as to special regulations.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: G.L. c. 85, § 11B further reflects the Commonwealth’s policy of protecting bicyclists as lawful users of the road and imposes duties on others to share the road safely with bicyclists.

Morin v. AutoZone, Inc., 79 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Morin v. AutoZone, Inc., 79 Mass. App. Ct. 39, 43–44 (2011)
Morin v. AutoZone, Inc., 79 Mass. App. C.proposition: It is well established that motorists owe a duty of care to bicyclists using the roadway, and that a driver who fails to look for a bicyclist before opening a car door into the bicyclist’s path may be found negligent.
Morin v. AutoZone, Inc., 79 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns asbestos exposure and product identification/causation in a wrongful death/products liability context; it does not address duties of motorists, bicyclists, or the specific scenario of opening a car door into a bicyclist’s path. Nothing in the court’s reasoning or holding discusses roadway users, traffic, or negligence standards for drivers toward cyclists. Therefore, this case cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition about motorists’ duty of care to bicyclists and dooring negligence.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359–60 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: It is well established that motorists owe a duty of care to bicyclists using the roadway, and that a driver who fails to look for a bicyclist before opening a car door into the bicyclist’s path may be found negligent.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion is about dram shop liability and the effect of violating a liquor service statute; it does not address duties of motorists to bicyclists, nor the specific scenario of opening a car door into a bicyclist’s path. There is no discussion of bicycle-vehicle interactions, roadway duties to cyclists, or dooring-related negligence. Thus the case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition and the citation is inapposite.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence, Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 327 (1982); Wiska v. St. Stanislaus Social Club, Inc., 7 Mass. App. Ct. 813, 816 (1979), meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Massachusetts courts define negligence as the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements of a negligence claim in Massachusetts and describes them in terms of a "duty of reasonable care," which is functionally equivalent to the standard of care of a reasonably prudent person under like circumstances. Although it does not use the exact phrasing of the proposition, its articulation of negligence as breach of a duty of reasonable care clearly aligns with the commonly stated Massachusetts definition invoked in the proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage." Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).

Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.proposition: Massachusetts courts define negligence as the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion discusses duties of reasonable care, foreseeability, comparative negligence, and intentional versus negligent conduct, but it does not set out or quote a definition of negligence. The proposition describes a specific negligence standard (“failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances”), and that language does not appear in or get articulated by this decision. Thus, this case is not proper authority for that precise definitional proposition.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.relevant_excerpt: Southland owed a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 [1973]) to prevent injury by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional (Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452 [1969]). Southland argues, however, that it owed no duty to the plaintiff in this case because the risk that led to the plaintiff's injury was not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant. Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646 (1990).

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 56–57 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts define negligence as the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpt provided is a dissent focused entirely on causation and foreseeability, not on the general definition of negligence. The only articulated standard in the text concerns proof that a defendant "took a risk" beyond what an ordinarily prudent person would take and that the injury was within the foreseeable risk, which is narrower and directed to proximate cause/foreseeability, not the baseline definition of negligence as failure to exercise reasonable care under like circumstances. Thus, this portion of Mullins does not clearly set out or affirm the general negligence definition stated in the proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Where a defendant’s negligence is a substantial factor in bringing about a plaintiff’s injuries, the defendant is liable for the resulting damages.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case discusses negligence, causation, and proximate cause, but it does not set out or apply a general rule that a defendant whose negligence is a substantial factor in bringing about injury is liable for resulting damages. Instead, the court finds that, as a matter of law, the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence was not the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries due to intervening and superseding causes. The opinion focuses on limits to liability, not on affirmatively establishing the substantial-factor-liability principle stated in the proposition.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “‘[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff.’ … In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.”

Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 255\u2.proposition: Where a defendant’s negligence is a substantial factor in bringing about a plaintiff’s injuries, the defendant is liable for the resulting damages.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 255\u2.support_reasoning: The court’s discussion is framed in terms of “proximate cause” and whether the defendant’s negligence remained an “operative and potent factor” in producing the death, even though a later infection was the immediate cause. That analysis is functionally equivalent to a substantial-factor conception of causation: if the negligent injury continued to operate by lowering vitality so that the infection became fatal, the defendant was liable for the resulting damages. The opinion does not use the phrase “substantial factor,” but its reasoning and result align with the proposition.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 255\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The proximate cause is that which in a continuous sequence, unbroken by any new cause, produces an event and without which the event would not have occurred. It may be assisted or accelerated by other incidental and ancillary matters, but, if it continues as an operative and potent factor, the chain of causation is not broken… The result of these decisions is that the primary cause may be the proximate cause, provided it continues to be efficiently, actively, and potently operative, although successive subsidiary instrumentalities may cooperate to produce the final result.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85, a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery if it is not greater than the total negligence of the person or persons against whom recovery is sought; any damages are diminished in proportion to the plaintiff’s comparative fault, if any.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: The duties of motorists to exercise reasonable care in using public ways arise from both common-law principles and statutes regulating the safe operation and stopping of motor vehicles.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 7.proposition: The duties of motorists to exercise reasonable care in using public ways arise from both common-law principles and statutes regulating the safe operation and stopping of motor vehicles.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85A.proposition: Damages recoverable in negligence under Massachusetts law include, inter alia, reasonable medical expenses, lost wages, compensation for pain and suffering, and property damage.

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Damages recoverable in negligence under Massachusetts law include, inter alia, reasonable medical expenses, lost wages, compensation for pain and suffering, and property damage.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability, duty to warn, evidentiary issues, consortium, and excessiveness of a lump-sum verdict, but it does not set out or analyze the specific elements of recoverable negligence damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or property damage. The only damages discussion is in the context of reviewing whether a $440,000 personal injury verdict was excessive, and even there the court lists specific injury-related factors rather than stating a general rule of what categories of damages are legally recoverable. Thus it does not provide authority for the broad damages proposition claimed.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

DiMarzo v. S. & P. Realty Corp., 364 Mas.raw_text: DiMarzo v. S. & P. Realty Corp., 364 Mass. 510, 515–16 (1974)
DiMarzo v. S. & P. Realty Corp., 364 Mas.proposition: Damages recoverable in negligence under Massachusetts law include, inter alia, reasonable medical expenses, lost wages, compensation for pain and suffering, and property damage.
DiMarzo v. S. & P. Realty Corp., 364 Mas.case_name: DiMarzo v. S. & P. REALTY CORP.
DiMarzo v. S. & P. Realty Corp., 364 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns landlord tort liability for negligent repairs and procedural issues about leading questions and directed verdicts. It does not discuss the categories or measure of damages recoverable in negligence, such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or property damage. No portion of the decision sets out or applies a rule about what elements of damages are recoverable, so it does not support the claimed proposition.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff is entitled to recover interest on a judgment in a tort action from the date of commencement of the action.
